title: Safety of Europe's largest nuclear plant relies on cooperation between Ukrainians and Russians
summary: Despite the war, Kyiv and Moscow are in conversation to maintain the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, now in occupied territory. The International Atomic Energy Agency has established itself as the sole interlocutor.

title: The extent of fraud in Russia's presidential election begins to emerge
summary: Vladimir Putin's record-breaking 87% of the vote is suspected to have been massively falsified. According to independent Russian media, the number of stolen votes varies between 22 million and 36 million, out of a total of 76 million voters.

title: 'Will China really become the world's leading economic power?'
summary: Economists are less and less certain that the Chinese economy can overtake the US, despite the promises of the Chinese Communist Party, writes Le Monde Beijing correspondent, Harold Thibault.

title: The rapid spread of a serious bacterial infection is causing concern in Japan
summary: The country is facing severe forms of invasive streptococcal A infections, which are spreading at a steady pace, and are fatal in one in three cases. Lax hygiene measures following the Covid-19 pandemic are thought to be contributing to the spread.

title: Irish prime minister's resignation leaves burning questions for his successor
summary: Leo Varadkar, Ireland's Taoiseach, unexpectedly stepped down, less than a year before the deadline for general elections.

title: M. Emmet Walsh, 'Blood Simple,' 'Blade Runner', 'Knives Out' actor, dies at 88
summary: Walsh died from cardiac arrest on Tuesday at a hospital in St. Albans, Vermont.

title: Free trade: Let's not equate CETA with Mercosur
summary: By putting CETA on the Sénat's agenda, France's Communists have aimed to draw on the anti-free-trade wave of farmers' protests. Yet this EU-Canada treaty must not be confused with Mercosur.

title: Campaign for India's general elections unfolds against a backdrop of political maneuvers
summary: In the run-up to the polls, which will be held from April 19 to June 1, the campaign has been marked by the scandal over 'electoral bonds,' a system of party financing that has largely favored Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party.

title: Saudi Arabia takes on debt to finance its megaprojects
summary: Petrodollars are no longer enough to keep pace with the investments required for 'Saudi Vision 2030,' the kingdom's huge economic diversification plan.

title: A TikTok trend highlights Paris suburbs' deteriorating schools
summary: Students in schools across Seine-Saint-Denis face water leaks in classrooms, insulation problems and mice. Teachers have raised the alarm about the deteriorating conditions, asking the government for an emergency plan.

title: New Banksy mural to be protected after London paint attack
summary: Islington Council, in north London, said it had erected fencing and camera surveillance  to protect the mural that appeared earlier this week.

title: War in Ukraine: EU considers using Russian frozen asset revenues for military aid to Kyiv
summary: The interest on these funds frozen in Brussels has yielded €4.4 billion in 2023. Some EU countries have suggested using a portion to supply arms to Ukraine. Others, such as France, have called for a European defense loan.

title: Sweden's arms industry is scaling up
summary: The world's 13th-largest arms exporter, NATO's most recent member has around 200 companies, all under pressure to produce more and faster.

title: Biden administration unveils stricter auto standards to speed electric shift
summary: The plan aims for a nearly 50% drop in fleet-wide emissions in 2032 compared with 2026  through higher, but the rules are moderated compared with preliminary standards unveiled last year.

title: Faced with record inflation, Egyptians tighten their belts for Ramadan
summary: Just before the start of the holy month, the Cairo authorities introduced a floating exchange rate, in line with IMF demands, cutting the local currency's value against the dollar by 6%.

title: Are penalties, as Didier Deschamps claims, really a lottery?
summary: Didier Deschamps, the coach of the French national football team, considers penalty shootouts to be primarily a game of chance. That is an increasingly anachronistic position.

title: By 2100, coastal erosion will have affected thousands of buildings in France
summary: An unpublished report analyzes the effects of rising seawaters on French coastlines. While there will be few consequences between now and 2028, the erosion will be much greater by 2050 and 2100.

title: Marine Le Pen's delicate approach to the international affairs
summary: While the far-right leader wants to be seen as the future French president, she has kept a low profile on current international issues – particularly Ukraine and Gaza – and has struggled to forge foreign connections.

title: Luis Montenegro appointed Portugal's prime minister
summary: His right-wing Democratic Alliance party won parliamentary elections on March 10.

title: The 'Madame Wing': How Brigitte Macron and her entourage influence the president
summary: In the east wing of the Elysée Palace, where the first lady's staff have their offices, one of her close advisers, Bruno Roger-Petit, has emerged as one of the most influential figures in the presidency.

title: US submits draft UN resolution calling for 'immediate ceasefire' in Gaza
summary: Washington calls 'for an immediate ceasefire linked to the release of the hostages, and we very much hope that countries will support it,' US Secretary of State told Saudi media.

title: Confiscation of criminal assets in France: 'We have redistributed over €272 million'
summary: The woman in charge of the agency that confiscates criminal assets in France is proud of a record-setting year. Agency Director Vanessa Perrée explains why this serves the public good and should be expanded.

title: Ukraine: Explosions heard in center of Kyiv
summary: A top US official said Wednesday that Washington could not predict when a vital $60-billion military aid package for Ukraine would be passed in Congress, as Volodymyr Zelensky called for Western air defenses after a Russian missile attack killed at least five.

title: All you need to know about CETA, the controversial EU-Canada trade agreement
summary: On March 21, French senators will vote on the final ratification of the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement, which has already been provisionally in force for seven years.

title: Indonesia's opposition candidate demands new vote after presidential election loss
summary: Anies Baswedan – who came second in the election with 24.9% of the votes, far behind the new president with 58.6% – denounced electoral 'cheatings and violations.'

title: Paris 2024 Olympics: USA and Spain handed tough draws in women's football
summary: The USA, Germany, and Australia were placed in the same group, world champions Spain face Brazil and Japan. Hosts France will take on Canada.

title: Paris 2024 Olympics: France drawn with USA and New Zealand in men's football
summary: Argentina will play Morocco and Ukraine in Group B, while Spain will face Egypt in Group C.

title: Israeli attacks on aid convoy escorts in Gaza jeopardize food distribution
summary: Civil servants and volunteers, helping to secure food trucks for Gazans, have been repeatedly targeted by Israeli fire.

title: Greenhouse gas emissions in France fell by 4.8% in 2023, twice as much as in 2022
summary: For the first time, the decline is common to all sectors, for reasons that are both structural, notably progress in energy renovation and electric vehicles,  and cyclical, such as energy prices and the weather.

title: In Israel, the rare voices of young people who refuse military service
summary: In a society that has made joining the army the symbol of belonging to Israel, a few young people refuse to do their military service every year. These voices advocating peace and coexistence with the Palestinians have become even more marginalized since the October 7 Hamas attacks.

title: Strike at France 24 has disrupted 18 days of broadcasting
summary: Technicians working in the master control room at the trilingual broadcaster are protesting against an increase in their workload without a pay rise.

title: How an EU-Canada trade agreement became a key electoral issue in France
summary: The CETA free-trade agreement between Canada and the European Union is set to be put to a vote by France's Sénat on Thursday. The opposition has seized an opportunity to score points, less than three months before the European elections.

title: Indonesian rescuers save 69 Rohingya refugees after boat capsizes
summary: Survivors estimated around 150 Rohingya refugees had been on board with dozens still missing and presumed lost at sea.

title: Paris 2024: Russia and the IOC reignite a cold war in world sport
summary: Moscow reacted sharply to the IOC's new restrictions on Russian athletes likely to take part in the Olympic Games.

title: Eight months from presidential election, the Fed risks being drawn into politics
summary: If re-elected, Donald Trump will not reappoint Jerome Powell to head the central bank. This could undermine the institution's independence, which is under pressure just a few months before the presidential election.

title: US Justice Department sues Apple, accusing it of smartphone monopoly
summary: The lawsuit filed by the federal agency and 16 state attorney generals alleges Apple has monopoly power in the smartphone market through its iPhones.

title: Russian spacecraft aborts launch to ISS
summary: Roscosmos, Russia's space agency, was set to launch the Soyuz MS-25 to bring 3 astronauts – from Russia, Belarus, and the US, in a rare display of cooperation – to the International Space Station. All were confirmed safe.

title: French senators reject EU-Canada free-trade deal
summary: The rejection of the CETA agreement, which has been in force provisionally since 2017, does not affect its application.

title: US surgeons perform world-first pig-to-human kidney transplant
summary: This 'major milestone' has been seen as something that will 'offer a lifeline to millions of patients worldwide,' as kidneys have long been in chronically short supply, which has disproportionately affected US ethnic minorities.
